report_title: Coal and Natural Gas Power Industry Report
executive_summary: The United States consumes 4.2 trillion kilowatt-hours of electricity and over half of that power is produced by the Coal and Natural Gas Power industry. Coal-based power has historically been the leading source of electricity in the United States. The outburst of natural gas availability and the implementation of burdensome environmental regulations have caused the industry to undergo a major structural transformation. Industry revenue is set to swell at a CAGR of 0.1% to $98.2 billion through 2024, including a 2.4% dip in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: United States relies on fossil fuels for electricity
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The United States relies upon fossil fuels to satisfy its massive appetite for electricity. While coal has historically been our nation's energy of choice, the dependency has recently shifted toward natural gas.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Coal's share of electric power declining
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Coal-fired power consistently accounted for more than half of total electricity generation in the US for the better part of the 20th century. Coal's share of total electric power has plunged since the beginning of 2012. Coal now accounts for only one-fifth of electricity generation in the US.

Many coal-fired power plants have retired as gas has gained popularity. According to the US Energy Information Administration (EIA), an average of 11.0 GW of coal was retired annually between 2015 and 2020. As of November 2023, power plant operators have retired 8.75 GW of coal-fired capacity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Natural gas key to sustainable future
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Gas-fired power will continue playing a major role in helping deliver affordable and sustainable power to households and industrial consumers for years to come. High-efficiency and low emissions combined cycle power plants will be integral to helping the United States achieve an independent and net-zero energy grid.

The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act has allocated $65.0 billion to upgrading the United States' power infrastructure. This includes investment in constructing new transmission lines and expanding the use of clean and renewable energy. It also includes funding for new carbon management.

Coal-fired plants with the highest operating and maintenance costs are most at risk of folding over the coming years. Inefficient power plants are increasingly forced to comply with costly environmental regulations and face extreme competition from gas-fired plants. According to the Energy Information Administration, more than one-fifth of the United States' coal-fired capacity is planned for retirement by the end of 2029.

Build Back Better and other federal regulations are making gas-fired power plants less attractive than renewable energy via crowding out the private sector. More states are adopting renewable portfolio standards (RPS) and clean energy standards (CES), requiring utilities to generate renewable energy as a percentage of their portfolio.

industry_definition: This industry operates fossil fuel-powered power plants, which burn coal and natural gas to power steam turbines that generate electricity. Industry operators sell generated power to regulated transmission and distribution utilities and on wholesale electricity markets. This industry does not include government-owned and operated power plants.

key_trends: Internal competition heats up with the growing prevalence of independent power producers (IPP). IPPs provide competition and choice for consumers and help to meet the growing need for low-cost electricity.
Gas- and coal-fired plants are staring down the barrel of a loaded gun. Decarbonization is currently a core mission in the United States and investment is piling into renewable energy.
Natural gas overtook coal as the leading source of electric power for the United States in 2016
Hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling have made shale gas deposits much more accessible. This is a major catalyst behind the growing capacity of gas-fired power in the United States.
Caithness Energy's Guernsey Power Station is the largest industry-relevant power plant currently in development. The power station will produce 1.9 megawatts of power via 3 combined-cycle units.

Tennessee Valley Authority is the nation's largest public power corporation by generating capacity. Its Cumberland coal-fired power plant produces more electricity than any industry-relevant operation.
Coal and natural gas power producers endure some of the most stringent regulations. Regulations can be markedly different based on how a company's energy is generated and transmitted.
Natural gas and coal prices significantly impact the financial performance of power plants. While prices have calmed down after skyrocketing since the pandemic, they still remain elevated.
A lack of skilled labor has changed how power plants look ahead. Power plants have demanded technologies that are easier to erect, maintain and upgrade.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The chemicals subsector (NAICS 325), petroleum and coal products subsector (324), primary metals subsector (331) and food subsector (311) are the largest consumers of gas- and coal-fired power in the United States. Industrial companies have consistent energy demands and often enter into wholesale power contracts to ensure stable prices.

The residential sector includes private households that consume electricity for lighting, heating, cooling, refrigeration and to power appliances. Residential power consumption varies based upon the location of the customer, type of structure and equipment choices. These underlying factors also play a major role in the type of energy source demanded by the customer.

Commercial customers include offices, hospitals, shopping centers, warehouses and manufacturers that are not large enough to be categorized as industrial consumers. While this segment was hampered during the pandemic because of shutdowns, it has recovered as the economy reopened. Some commercial businesses are now adopting renewable energy systems, thanks to recently extended tax credits.

products_and_services.product_description: A natural gas power plant is an industrial facility that converts thermal energy emitted from the heating of natural gas into electrical energy for use in a power grid.
Coal power plants burn steaming coal in a boiler to produce steam that is used to spin a turbine and generate electricity.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Electric power consumption represents the total amount of electricity consumed in the United States, more than one-half of which is derived from coal and natural gas power. As electric power consumption increases, the need for the electricity produced by coal and natural gas power plants rises as well, leading to growth in industry revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The significant number of power plants in this region reflects the fact that this geography also holds the largest population. More power plants locate in this area to satisfy higher demand for electricity. Louisiana has the highest energy consumption per capita than any other state, according to the Energy Information Administration (EIA). West Virginia has the seventh-highest energy consumption per capita in the United States. The Southeast continues to transition its energy reliance away from coal and toward more sustainable and affordable energy, namely natural gas.

This region's importance to the industry is because of its abundant reserves of natural gas in the Haynesville, Eagle Ford and Permian shale plays. Texas has consumed more energy than any other state for every recorded year, according to the EIA. Its gas-fired power plants are crucial to supply electricity to this massive grid.

This region mainly falls within the Midcontinent independent system operator, which operates the transmission and dispatch markets in 15 states throughout the Great Lakes and Plains. Coal-fired power is prevalent in this region due to its substantial industrial base and the early establishment of power generation in the region. The Great Lakes continues to add new gas-fired power capacity as more transportation infrastructure becomes added to the region. Illinois, Michigan and Ohio are planned to have the greatest addition in gas-powered capacity over the next several years.
The Mid-Atlantic region is home to major urban centers in Northeastern United States with significant demand for electricity.
The Plains region has seen varied energy demands but plays a role in the overall supply chain.
The Western United States has seen a growing incorporation of renewable energy sources, impacting traditional electrical generation.
The Rocky Mountains region is poised for both traditional and renewable energy development.
New England has been transitioning towards cleaner electricity sources with ongoing regulatory changes.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This act sets forth an energy research and development program covering energy efficiency, renewable energy, oil and gas, coal and electricity. The program establishes tax and loan incentives for investing in natural gas and producing electricity from renewable resources. This act also provided transmission system access to wholesale suppliers.

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) acts as an economic regulator for interstate transmission of electricity. The agency oversees reliability standards for bulk power systems and is required to set just and reasonable wholesale electricity prices. The commission's legal authority is derived from the Federal Power Act. FERC regulates wholesale transmission rates and cost recovery which can influence infrastructure investment and retail prices at the state level.

This federal law develops national ambient air quality standards to protect human and environmental health. This law was enacted in 1955, with major revisions in 1970, 1977 and 1990 to better address toxic air pollutants, acid rain and regional haze. One method of reducing emissions from coal-fired power was to burn low-sulfur coal found mainly in the West.

This act enables the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to regulate the discharge of pollutants into waters. The law makes it unlawful to discharge any pollutant into navigable waters, unless a permit is obtained.

This regulation replaced the 2015 Clean Power Plan, which was ruled to have exceeded the EPA's authority permitted by the Clean Air Act. The new rule promotes energy independence and establishes emissions guidelines for coal-fired power plants.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Guidelines
regulations_points.regulation_description: The EPA publishes effluent limitation guidelines (ELGs) that regulate wastewater discharges from power plants. ELGs are national regulations that set technology-based numeric limits for specific pollutants. These guidelines were first announced in 1974 and have been amended several times over the years.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Disposal of Coal Combustion Residuals from Electric Utilities
regulations_points.regulation_description: In 2014, the EPA Administrator finalized this comprehensive set of requirements for the safe disposal of coal ash produced from coal-fired power plants.
In 2011, the EPA announced sweeping technology-based emission standards for mercury and other hazardous air pollutants emitted by units with more than 25.0 megawatts of capacity.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has high capital intensity.
The industry has low to increasing assistance level.

basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition heats up with the growing prevalence of independent power producers (IPP).
Gas- and coal-fired plants face pressure from decarbonization efforts and investment in renewable energy.

concentration_points.concentration_description: In deregulated markets, independent system operators (ISO) and regional transmission organizations (RTO) promote competition.
Companies are investing in renewable resources through mergers and acquisitions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Consistent infrastructure upgrades and investments are critical to the success of electric power generators. Companies must construct new turbines and generators and also purchase batteries and transformers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Coal and Natural Gas Represent the Industry's Main Purchase Cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Power generators are responsible for consuming more coal and natural gas than any other type of business in the United States. Purchasing fossil fuels is costly and represents the single-largest expense for coal- and gas-fired power plants.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Most power plants fulfill their fuel requirements via firm contracts
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Most power plants fulfill their fuel requirements via firm contracts, providing them with a steady fuel supply at an agreed-upon price. Amid volatile commodity prices, having access to a stable and low-cost energy supply is essential to maximizing profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Automation Leads to a Fall in Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Power plants require highly specialized workers like plant and systems operators, maintenance and repair staff, architects, engineers, information clerks and material moving workers. While skilled employees are essential, many power plants implement automation technology to reduce wage costs and bolster profitability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Improves With The Passage of Rate Hikes
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Power plants purchase and burn steaming coal and natural gas to produce electricity and obtain supply contracts from coal mines and natural gas distributors to deliver these energy sources at a specified price. These contracts are often long-term agreements that aim to reduce the exposure of price fluctuations to both parties. Although the prices of fossil fuels have been historically volatile, average industry profit has generally remained stable. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and public utility commissions have also granted favorable electricity rates hikes periodically to give the electricity producer a reasonable opportunity to recover its costs and provide a profit to investors.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Highly skilled engineers and technicians are absolutely necessary to ensure that a power plant is running safely and efficiently as well as to conduct repair and maintenance work. Although these workers are essential to producing power, the industry is significantly more reliant on capital than labor.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Energy and Electricity Prices are Constantly Changing
volatility_points.volatility_description: Steaming coal and natural gas are traded on a global scale and the prices of these commodities are constantly shifting to match supply and demand. The prices of these integral energy inputs have been especially volatile after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and public utility commissions are responsible for setting wholesale and retail utility rates, a process known as rate design. State regulators set a base rate charged to the customer for the cost of providing the services, plus a profit. Regulated utilities companies can file for a rate increase to recover higher operating costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Electricity Demand is Affected by Seasonal Factors
volatility_points.volatility_description: Seasonal variation affects the industry's major markets to various degrees. Industrial and commercial markets experience the least seasonal change in demand for electricity, while residential consumers have the greatest seasonal variation. In parts of the United States with hotter climates, demand for power peaks during the hot summer months due to the increased use of air conditioning systems. In colder areas, power demand peaks during the winter due to the high demand for heating. The pattern of this fluctuation may vary due to the nature and location of the plant and its customers as well as the terms of its power sale contracts.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Gas-fired power plants have become much more efficient at producing electricity over the past several decades. The average natural gas-fired combined-cycle power block capacity was less than 400.0 megawatts in 2000. According to the Energy Information Administration, the national average has climbed to more than 700.0 megawatts in recent years. 75.0% of all combined-cycle power plants use duct burners to increase the amount of electricity produced via the system's steam turbine. The most common configuration for a combined-cycle system is two gas and one steam turbine.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Decentralized Power Plants Provide Energy Flexibility
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many small-scale gas-fired power plants are being installed to provide local energy grids with low-cost power. These highly efficient power plants can provide additional energy to areas where the grid is unreliable or where supply is insufficient to meet demand. Small-scale gas plants can be implemented relatively quickly compared to larger facilities. This allows for a rapid response to energy needs and can be crucial in emergency situations.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by imported energy from Canada?
FAQs.answer: While exports and imports are technically not broken down by resource, imports from Canada are minimal for companies in this industry. Companies that will experience the highest amount of import challenges will be located along the border.

FAQs.question: Have volatile input prices changed the energy sources your company uses to generate electricity over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Declines in the price of natural gas drive many companies to purchase and generate electricity from this resource. Negative sentiment towards coal over the past decade has pushed the need for gas.

FAQs.question: Have volatile input prices affected your company over the past few years? How have you adapted?
FAQs.answer: Large declines in the price of natural gas can lead many companies to generate electricity from this resource. Generating electricity from a resource that is less expensive has enabled companies to increase their profit.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry rely on a large amount of skilled labor. To retain talented employees companies must offer high salaries and competitive benefits packages.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new renewable technology, such as wind- and solar-generated energy, in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Many companies generate electricity from a diversified range of resources. The Production Tax Credits (PTC) and Investment Tax Credits (ITC) continue to push downstream markets to invest in wind and solar projects.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by the growth of electricity generated by renewable resources?
FAQs.answer: Growth in renewable energy can take away demand from natural gas companies. Many states have Renewable Portfolio Standards in order to set targets on the amount of renewable energy used to generate electricity in a state.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: To ensure health and safety, companies must adhere to all regulatory workplace protocols and implement proper training for employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations?
FAQs.answer: The push towards renewable energy has caused many states to implement clean energy targets. Companies operating in these states must diversify their energy generation portfolio to stay ahead of these regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon, such as new generation plants or transmission lines, that require capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Many companies will invest in constructing smaller, more efficient plants to capitalize on lower prices. Low-interest rate environments lead companies to more infrastructure investment or refinancing.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Companies that invested in natural gas based generation likely garnered the highest profit. Larger companies can invest in cost-saving technologies to bolster profit.

FAQs.question: Do you operate near optimum capacity? Do you continually align capacity to demand? What improvements can you implement to improve overall efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Higher capacity utilization is necessary for optimum operating efficiency. During periods of high demand, producers may operate closer to optimum capacity to capitalize on market conditions and generate higher revenues.

FAQs.question: How do you keep track of the company's expenditures? What costs can you cut back on? Are there any systems you can use to effectively control costs?
FAQs.answer: Strategic financial management, taking into account trends in input prices, interest rates and downstream demand, is crucial in maximizing profit margins.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to successfully negotiate with the FCC? How have new regulations affected your capital expenditures and operating costs?
FAQs.answer: The ability to negotiate a regulatory environment that can vary substantially across states is crucial to success in this industry.

FAQs.question: How would you respond to changes in utilities consumption? What plans do you have in place to expand industry revenue?
FAQs.answer: The value of utilities construction measures the amount of capital spent annually on the construction of power plants.

FAQs.question: How does declining natural gas prices impact your company?
FAQs.answer: Natural gas, a major input in industry operations, is gradually becoming a more important fuel source in electricity generation. Declining natural gas prices benefit the industry by reducing industry purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How will you take advantage of an increase in levels of industrial production? How can you incorporate specialized and value-added services?
FAQs.answer: The industrial production index measures total production from the manufacturing, mining and utility sectors.
